item.title: The Ultimate Guide to Retirement Planning
item.ns1:encoded:
Ask anyone who's retired, and they will say to start saving for retirement as soon as you can!

Even if it seems a long way away, it pays to start planning for retirement as early as possible. How much you need to save will depend on your circumstances, but the sooner you start, the better the position you’ll be in when you eventually stop working. 

While NZ Super (the government pension) can help get you by, it's your savings and investments that will help to make retirement more comfortable and enjoyable. 


In this guide

  • Calculate how much you will need to retire

  • Figure out where your retirement money will come from

  • Should I get rid of debt before retirement?

  • Are trusts worth it?


Calculate how much you'll need for retirement.

Everyone has different retirement demands. To figure yours out, consider how long you might be retired, what kind of lifestyle you'd like, and where you'll reside. 


How many years of retirement should I plan for?

Nowadays, people live longer lives. On average, 65-year-old females can expect to live to 86 years old, and males can expect to live to 83. And then what happens to your retirement funds if you live until 95? You’re going to want to factor that possibility in.

There is no 'retirement age' in New Zealand. NZ Super is paid from the age of 65, but you do not have to quit working to receive it. More and more people are working beyond the age of 65, whether full-time or part-time.

Let’s assume you plan to retire at 65. You would need to save and invest or have another way to supply enough income for 25-30 years or more, while also ensuring that your money is going to last as long as you do.

What type of retirement lifestyle do I want?

How much would it cost you to live in retirement? Some prices may rise (such as healthcare), while others (such as education, clothing, housing, and business trips) may fall (especially if you have children, they will likely be financially independent when you retire).

Would you rather live a no-frills or choices lifestyle? The first is rather simple, while the second is more comfortable, with some extras and bonuses. For example, a couple living in Wellington may have a more flexible lifestyle that costs $1423 per week, whereas a pair living somewhere more rural like Levin may pay less, at $1137.

You should also consider your retirement goals, such as travelling overseas, joining clubs, and attending dinners and shows. Much of this is determined by your 'bucket list'. If you don’t have a bucket list, start with our Goal Planning Worksheet.

Will I rent, have a mortgage, or own my home entirely in retirement?

Renting requires more funds to cover the cost, but you will not have money invested in a property. If you decide to retire with a mortgage, you will need to plan accordingly.

Owning a debt-free home eliminates the danger of rent rises or having to move. You will have more control over your funds, but you will be responsible for maintenance, insurance, and rates.

Being mortgage-free by retirement is an excellent goal to strive toward. Many people in retirement can manage their finances since they no longer have to worry about mortgage payments.

Once you have thought about how you want your retirement life to look, have a play with our Spending Planner and map out how much you want to spend in each area during your retirement. 

Determine where your retirement money will come from.

Given that you could be retired for 30 years, you will require a steady income. Most New Zealand residents over 65 receive NZ Super every fortnight.

Approximately 40% of New Zealanders over the age of 65 rely only on NZ Super. However, most retired New Zealanders rely on their savings in addition to NZ Super.

Check out the current rates for NZ Super. Is that enough to survive on?

There will most likely be a difference between the income provided by NZ Super and the income you want in retirement. As a result, when planning for retirement, you'll need to consider other options.

If you know your weekly, fortnightly or monthly retirement expenses, or you utilised our Spending Plan, you can easily find out your income gap by identifying the shortfall between how much the NZ Super will provide you with and your total expenses. 


NZ Super

NZ Superannuation is a government-paid pension for most New Zealand residents over 65.

NZ Super benefits all eligible New Zealanders, regardless of income, assets, or taxes paid. Here's all you need to know about New Zealand Super, including this year's rates.


Savings and Investments

You may want to use the money you have saved and invested to fund your retirement years. Use our Savings/Investments Calculator to determine how much to save and invest towards your retirement objectives. Setting long-term goals can help you decide how to invest.

The more reliant you are on your savings, the more conservative or 'protective' your investment strategy should be.

Once you've saved for retirement, you'll need to make smart decisions about how to stretch it out over the next 30 years or more. Our Goal Planning System does a fantastic job of displaying your money in a way that makes ensuring it lasts so simple. Book a chat with an adviser to learn more and see how we can help make your money last. 


KiwiSaver

KiwiSaver's unique perks make it an excellent choice for retirement savings.

KiwiSaver members get annual government payments of up to $521 for free, in addition to your contributions and a minimum of 3% of their pay from their employers if they are working. A KiwiSaver provider then invests all of that money, which grows as a result of the returns earned. This extra money means that your savings will yield larger returns than another plan in which you are the sole contributor. This will make it easier to meet your retirement savings target.

When you reach the age of 65 and are ready to utilise your KiwiSaver funds to support your retirement, you can set up regular withdrawals with your provider.

Use our KiwiSaver Calculator to predict your future returns.



Working during retirement.

People continue to work in retirement for a number of reasons: many enjoy the work or need the money, while others may need to stop completely due to health issues. Approximately one-third of Kiwis continue to work after the age of 65. You can continue to work as usual or change your working arrangements, such as flexible hours, part-time or casual jobs, consultancy, or mentorship.

Your NZ Super entitlement is unaffected by your income from paid work. However, it may have an impact on your eligibility for income-tested benefits like the Accommodation Supplement and Disability Allowance. For further information, contact Senior Services at 0800 552 002.

Downsizing Your Home

Selling a property and buying a smaller one in a less expensive neighbourhood can help you save money while still delivering the benefits of home ownership.

You may intend to downsize and relocate to the regions when you retire, but this does not always work out exactly as planned. There are trade-offs to make in terms of social network and access to amenities, so living closer to a city centre may still be better.

Reverse mortgages

If you own a home or other property and need to free up funds for long-term living needs, emergencies, or a significant expense, you can use a reverse mortgage.

You can borrow against your property in a flat payment or draw down the loan as needed. In the meantime, interest payments accumulate. When you die or the property is sold, the full loan plus interest must be returned, resulting in a lesser inheritance.

When considering a reverse mortgage, it is advisable to consult with family and seek independent financial and legal advice. It is critical to understand how the product works and what it may cost (including fees and interest costs). When calculating cost forecasts, you can employ a 'worst-case scenario' approach rather than assuming a property's value will improve. Speak to one of our mortgage experts to see if a reverse mortgage could be for you.


Other ways to generate income from your home

There are other options you can consider to release value from your home:

  • Rent out part of your home

  • Take in a boarder

  • Subdivide your property

  • Sell your home to family or whānau (while retaining the right to live in it)


Should I get rid of my debt before retiring?

Paying off debt in retirement might be challenging, so make it a goal to be debt-free before you retire. To begin your retirement strategy, prioritise paying off any high-interest debt, such as credit cards or hire purchases. 


Whether to pay off the mortgage or not

The next objective is to pay off your mortgage before retiring, but this should not be your primary retirement strategy.

Mortgage interest can exceed after-tax savings returns, with the exception of KiwiSaver due to incentives.

However, there are hazards in delaying major retirement savings until after you've paid off your mortgage. You may end up with a mortgage for longer than expected due to changes in your circumstances, such as illness or job loss, that limit your ability to make repayments. A life-changing event, such as separation, can disrupt your plans.

The short version is that it is ideal to pay off debt, pay off your mortgage, and save for retirement at the same time.

Are trusts worthwhile?

People typically create trusts so that they no longer legally own their home or other assets, but can still use and enjoy them as 'beneficiaries' of the trust. The most frequent forms of trusts used by retirees are family trusts and burial trusts, which should be thoroughly researched beforehand to ensure they perform as intended.

Family trusts

Family trusts entail selling assets to a trust, such as a house. Family trusts can be complicated and time-consuming to manage. It costs money to put them up, and there are continuous legal and accounting expenses. 

Prepaid funeral trusts

Prepaid funeral trusts allow you to pay for funeral expenditures in advance. Funeral trusts worth up to $10,000 are not considered assets when Senior Services determines eligibility for the Residential Care Subsidy.

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #1 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
We are thrilled to announce the launch of "Thoughts from the Chair," a captivating new blog by our esteemed Chairman, John Killick! Stay tuned for his thought-provoking insights in the upcoming blog posts as we embark on this exciting journey together.

Accepting personal responsibility

I’m not sure if others are feeling the frustration that I do as our society and community appear so disrupted and disaffected at the present, yet our leaders seem entrenched in the maintenance of power and control. It reminds me of my teenage years (the 60s) when Mum and Dad ‘were always right’ – to my chagrin. But they missed the revolution of change occurring around us at the time, it was a fast-moving societal sensation.

  • Rock music

  • The contraceptive pill

  • 10 o’clock closing

  • The arrival of cannabis

  • The Vietnam War 

  • The hippie generation – freedom vs fiefdom

It felt wonderful and invigorating – we didn’t totally reject the norms, but we pushed the boundaries. That’s not the liberal environment I see now with our Millennials and Gen Zs. At least not from my perception. As a teenager I recognised and welcomed the dialogue and debate of the time – but I also observed that not all ‘authority’ was as portrayed. One only had to observe behaviours at sporting clubs, theatre, and community gatherings to witness the reality of life – from parents, teachers, policemen, firemen, professionals, councillors, business owners, iwi, let alone politicians. They were not then nor are they now, above reproach. 

It is possible to disagree and debate without reverting to caterwauling and the shouting down of people with dissenting views – which we see on one hand whilst on the other this seemingly blind acceptance of authoritarian directive. What of those fast-moving societal sensations of today, what are they and do we see the ‘party’ of the 60s, the careless days of the 70s or the ‘pain’ of the 80s – or is it the ‘prescription’ of the 2020s – prescribed by politicians, medical professionals, and public service personnel?

  • Climate

  • Social media

  • Political progressivism

  • Gender and Racism

  • Mental health / suicide

  • Influencers – media moguls, authoritarian regimes, pharmaceuticals, big tech, unelected officials, the rich and ‘famous’

  • War in Europe

  • The collapse of societal balance (divisions) (personality vs policy) (party vs people)

You’ll note the difference from the 60s model – we were on happy pills – the modern young generation is overly prescribed, not for fun and frivolity but with anti-depressants.

My point?

In a few months, the country gets an opportunity to select our representatives and thereby our government. Our progressive future as a country and community however, will not come from political parties and politicians – it will come from us – all genders, races, religions – all beliefs, occupations, professions – all types, academics, artists, sports personnel, farmers – willing to reconsider who really deserves ‘control’, aspiration, purpose. Power is a powerful drug and if we give it to a person or an organisation less deserving than ourselves, they will seldom relinquish it voluntarily.

Correct knowledge gives ultimate power from the truth – but one needs to check the source, not all are trustworthy. Terrible regimes both current and of the past were created by immoral and corrupt politicians and power brokers who preyed upon trusting citizens too easily manipulated by storytellers, orators, and their codifying toadies.

We should vote with knowledge and conscience but contribute by way of purpose, productivity, and the power of love – yourself, your family, your community. It will pay dividends many times over in comparison to hoping it will come from a political party. And whatever political party and or arrangement of same under the current MMP constituency – remember they are only ‘contractors’ – the true power rests in the bowels of the ‘public service’. The unelected officials and bureaucrats of the ‘deep state’ and they don’t change at elections – but you can because living life on purpose, with wellness, meaning, and security is what life is really all about and we only have one shot at it. So, hold your nose and vote but smile and get on with living – enjoying times with those you love – I can recommend it!

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #3 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
First things first

I suspect the entrepreneurial spirit and management capability were initially imbued in me as a youngster watching and learning from my parents. Both of whom ran separate businesses and did so collaboratively. They worked well together and we kids were an integral part of each. A café/milk bar/dairy, and a four-car taxi service – with a speciality in weddings. 7-day-a-week services (and for the taxi service, 24 hours a day) This was in the 50s and 60s in small town NZ. The town had four pubs, two banks, a post office, two constables and a sergeant of police, a traffic officer, two doctors, (both of whom did house calls) four primary schools, a secondary school, a picture theatre, memorial hall, a maternity home, old peoples home, Jaycees, Lions, Rotary, Little theatre, senior rugby and cricket teams, a golf club – and an industry which employed a large number of workers and paid them well (I know because I helped fill their pay packets every week at the CBA bank) The manufacturer – NZ Woolpacks and textiles – making woolpacks from flax. The flax cutters were the big earners (and spenders)

Most of us that have built a business or managed a business at a senior level know that ‘dealing with change’ is necessarily a primary focus – or needs to be. One cannot afford to go to sleep at the wheel. The same for life. People develop experience in many ways, the more experience we have, the better we get. In business, an important focus is to make a profit. In life, it is surely wellness, meaning, contribution, and peace of mind. But just as small-town NZ no longer has the same level of services and industry it once provided to its citizens, the drivers of change which affected business are the same for families – and the answers are no different.

What took generations to create, service and supply in Foxton – changed in 20 years, dramatically. The same in Tokoroa where I lived, worked, and started a family in the 70s. In both instances, the manufacturing industry changed the landscape – because the owners were responding to their environment. They needed to change to survive. The most common initiator of the need for change in business will be a weakening of financial performance. Most stresses in life stem from monetary issues. Next for both – probably the impact these days of new technologies and their effect upon our social and business structure. If we felt a two-decade transition created chaos just imagine the impact of AI. We’ve recently experienced banks in the US go broke overnight – bank runs can now happen in hours due to technology and instant settlements.

When I left college and joined the financial services industry in Foxton our currency system in NZ was – pounds, shillings, and pence! All / most transactions were with coins and paper (cheques and notes) We manually calculated fees and interest – there were no mortgage loans for housing (that remained with solicitor trust funds and Building societies). The same year I left banking, the US government cut the link between gold reserves and money. Today banks lend close to 90% of money with no reserves. They rely on people not all wishing to withdraw their savings at the same time. In some Western countries governments will bail out banks or at least create a minimum guarantee for depositors’ savings. Not in NZ. Once a saver in NZ deposits their money in the bank – they (you) no longer own it, you have lent it to the bank. In 2016 in India, their government directed money through the banking system by eliminating legal tender via the removal of large currency notes. The big agenda. A cashless society. Control – but not by you. In Europe and Japan, negative interest rates have meant savers/depositors were charged interest. A cashless society also provides authoritative governments with the ability to take taxes on the spot, create instant fines with instant payment, and switch off credit. Imagine the business not operating with ESG requirements or the individual having their credit cancelled at the airport just as they were to take a holiday in Fiji! Sounds improbable, it's already happening.

The capability for AI to change the landscape is immense – whole industries will be threatened. Artificial intelligence can respond to unscripted questions on any subject to create entirely new content, based on data its had access to - with a steadily increasing development and role. New AI has smart video recognition (for example – just type in raw instruction) it can create bespoke background music (not existing tunes – it makes its own), sound effects, captions, and storyboards. (All from raw request) Think it might change marketing and business? You bet!

If we don’t keep changing, if we don’t keep improving, if we don’t keep innovating, if we don’t stay alert – our destiny will be determined more and more by an authoritative overseer or system we will regret. The transformation needs to come from the bottom up (the people) not the top down – the power brokers, politicians, and big corporates. First things first means we focus on what’s important in life to get ourselves sorted as a first step - that enables us to plan and prepare for what may be coming around the corner via disruption, and change – whether positive or negative. It’s called life-stage planning and it starts with getting clarity of purpose.

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #4 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
Think win/win

The major source of information in today's ‘enlightened’ world emanates from, mainstream media, social media, and political PR – it’s hardly win/win.

Often in life, sport, and business, we are dealt ‘cards’ which are seemingly loaded against us and how we play the hand determines our destiny. Some prosper, for others, it gets too hard. The NZ statistics for prescribed anti-depressants for those up to the age of 19, went from 5% in 2018 to 18% in 2021. For those aged 19 – 21, it doubled. And if we were to obtain statistics which relate to the opposite end of NZ demographics (people in rest homes) I think we would be astounded – although I think they are prescribed for very different reasons.

Recent information from a large NZ health insurer tells us that claims (all health issues) have gone from 400/500 per day pre-pandemic to 700 per day post-pandemic. Wellington regional hospitalisations – heart attacks up 83%, stroke 25%, myocarditis 33%, acute kidney issues 40%. Our hospitals are train wrecks – it’s no wonder, these are frightening statistics, and the hospitals are filled with vaccinated covid patients, but you wouldn’t know it unless you moved beyond government propaganda.

Life insurance companies price their premiums on morbidity and mortality – related to demographics. The pricing will inevitably increase. Those ‘smart’ clients that levelled their premiums will be eternally grateful to their insurance advisers and life-stage planners. For those that remain on yearly renewable term insurance, the reality is coming. Actuaries at all life insurance companies will be in close accord with their senior management bosses, their boards, and their owners. I can sense the tensions in the board rooms as ‘sales and marketing’ argue the case with ‘finance’. Finance will win and premiums will go up, as people are dying and becoming incapacitated at a much earlier age (in fact – working ages). The narrative is ‘long covid’ – we’ll know in time if that is truly the cause.

Thank goodness the four courageous Colombian children (aged 13, 9, 4, and 11 months) listened to their mother. “leave me and go find food” Grandma said (via search and rescue) “Stay where you are so it’s easier to find you” 40 days later the kids are found – alive. Sometimes mixed messages confuse – and we need to make a choice, at times the messenger seems so sincere and believable that we succumb to the devious and deliberate deception. Other times people or organisations seem so ravingly antagonistic, arrogant, or unbelievable we completely block out anything they might say or do – regardless of the truth. A couple of extreme examples are Mayor Wayne Brown – in Auckland, and Orange Man Donald Trump – in the US.

In a recent article by Bruce Cotterill in the Herald he referred to feedback on Brown's mayoralty performance – much of it extremely positive. But you wouldn’t think it from the narrative in mainstream media. Those of us that have visited Auckland in the last few years know the place is hardly running in a bath of oil. Something or someone needed to change. Besides, we are experiencing similar frustrations in Wellington. Both Wellington and Washington are deeply political – centres for their political governance – both filled with unelected but politically appointed officials. When Trump was elected in 2016 on a platform of ‘draining the swamp’ he had no idea, any more than the rest of us, just how deep the swamp was, or how dirty. It is only now as their country and ours head to elections that the true depth of bureaucracy and ‘spin’ from PR doctors of deception are becoming more divisive and parochial. (Hardly win/win)

The little 13-year-old Colombian girl trusted her dying mother, then took the initiative. Left her dead and dying parents and moved deeper into the jungle with her siblings in search of sustenance. The story and the message are incredibly empowering – the outcome unbelievable – the children found safe and well in an environment she was accustomed to but not one that was anything like home. I suspect that social media has a lot to do with the increase in medicated antidepressants for our NZ young people – and I doubt their Mum is who they have been listening to. The problem is that when they inevitably do (listen to Mum) and return for her cooking, comfort, and security – they will pay the price of permanent damage – either mental or metabolic – just as many in our country are now experiencing post covid vaccinations. We now know that what we thought was a vaccine is not – but a gene therapy. Whilst our politicians and their ‘expert’ advisers were convinced their mandates and directives were in our ‘best interest’ (ie win/win) I’m not as convinced that big pharma was motivated in the same way.

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #5 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
KiwiSaver Rental Bond Policy

National’s KiwiSaver rental bond policy should not be seen as being worthy of debate. It is neither a profoundly positive and socially impactful policy for renters nor a hugely negative policy for retirement planners. It is purely political. Unfortunately, political incentives get votes and democracies count people’s heads and not what’s in them.

I paraphrase Vernon Small (former adviser to Labour minister David Parker) “In the tightly fought election campaign in 2005 Labour needed a circuit-breaker, the interest-free student loan policy boosted support because it had inter-generational appeal. Not just to students but also to parents and grandparents who saw the burden of debt driving family members overseas and delaying decisions to buy homes or start families. Robertson was key to the development of that loan policy”. Unquote. Labour retained power for the next three years, Michael Cullen introduced KiwiSaver in 2007 and National won the next election in 2008 (there were tough times to follow in Wellington / NZ / world – as thousands of public servants were made redundant, employers had to stump up with an additional 3% for KiwiSaver contributions, and the global financial crisis impacted with job losses and the greatest economic downturn since the great depression)

Politicians will make it happen again – Labour will not hesitate to proffer direct payments to ‘deserving’ voters – or proffer subsidies for housing, home loans, or reconsider GST – especially on food. The same for National, Greens, Act, and NZ First.

Unfortunately, the more politicians interfere with the fundamentals of capitalism – the more they need to find solutions for the disruption they have caused through the interference. The cycle of ‘good ideas’ ‘justifiable governance oversight’ ‘poor policy’ (lacking in due diligence, budgetary control, good managerial implementation) ‘bureaucratic inefficiencies’ (complex central planning) ‘bad outcomes’ (health, education, law and order, government spending, debt) – inevitably follow.

Interest-free loans are a good example. Any experienced business owner knows that incentives to gain new business can be a double-edged sword. They will likely appeal to a ‘market’ – but seldom with long-term profitable benefits and almost always with customers who treat a ‘free lunch’ as their right – and behave in just that way. They become a servicing and support nightmare. Whilst several excuses for universities in NZ going broke have been proffered to the current government in an endeavour to secure further funding (successfully), interest-free student loans are now a huge debt conundrum for many students (some of whom have opted out and legged it from the country) and especially the incumbent government. (Whilst this op-ed is not the appropriate vehicle to discuss current education standards emanating from universities, I would have to say it is the drawing of a long bow to say that ‘capability, knowledge, and skill’ has improved – over the last 20 years because of ‘free entry’.

Whilst KiwiSaver is such an attractive source of ‘free money’ for politicians – more and more ‘good ideas’ will abound as gaining power by gaining votes becomes more important than delivering policy with trustworthiness and authenticity. Power is an ‘A’ class drug – and those with it seldom like to give it up. They are not in it for you.

There is no point in debating a financial product (introduced and sponsored by a government), through financial rationale. The originator and the product deserve the greatest of accolades – it was tough for employers at the time (2008) but of necessity, they have adapted – but now the lid is off the lolly jar – other people’s money has always been an attractive option for authoritarian regimes. We will see more of it before this election is over.

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #6 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
Seek first to understand

Whilst sitting in the back of the family car (and I can’t remember the catalyst for the ensuing commentary – probably me not doing my homework) my father promoted an interesting consideration for a first-year college student – one mostly interested in sport. “School is where you learn how to learn”. I’m not sure I got the full insight into the wisdom from his assertion; however, it has stuck with me – listen, read, write, consider, question, measure success. That didn’t mean we were afforded the same opportunity around the dinner table.

In lifestage planning understanding clients, intentions and aspirations is fundamental – they are not easily obtained but essential if the destination and journey are to be road mapped and implemented successfully over the long term. ‘Seek first to understand before being understood’ (habit 5 in Stephen Covey’s 7 Habits) is basic stuff through a lifestage planner’s career – whether promoting products, advising fee-based business development planning for SMEs, proffering lending options for homeowners, or delivering investment and retirement planning recommendations in an environment of constant financial and market change with associated client anxiety. Clarity of purpose and insight into people's desired lifestyle (for a lifetime) and their cash management – is important. Health, Money, and Relationships are interrelated – fail at one and all are compromised. Each is requiring of attention over a protracted period. There is no short-term fix or simple answer – and most of us know that or get to know that.

Why then are our ‘superior’ houses of learning (Universities) in such a sorry state? And not just financial. If knowledge and research are such important contributors to our society – how come the academic community along with their funders, got it so wrong? Or is there a blame environment where the funding party (77% of university funding comes from the taxpayer) is accused of serial underfunding whilst the government says that universities have financial autonomy; they are responsible for their own finances and it's not the governments place to intervene in operational matters. The irony of course is that two former student association presidents (Hipkins and Robertson) are presiding over some of the deepest funding cuts to NZ universities in our political history. Hipkins at VuW and Robertson Otago. “The solution to this problem lies within the government – the way to avoid redundancies is for the government to increase funding” Chris Hipkins in the year 2000. Chris, of course, was to ultimately become the Minister of Education in the Ardern government for 5 years. In reality, the country is bearing the brunt of the pandemic as a whole – we all have been affected, but in the case of universities, they got the ‘quaddy’ – declining domestic enrolment, high inflation, seriously depleted international enrolments, and the inability to receive the governments wage subsidy scheme through lockdowns and lockouts. Redundancies are the outcome – and lots of them. For all my criticism of the university curriculum and questionable student qualification and capability, I’m not sure that losing up to 1,000 people from the academic and research sector is smart – unless the new model means operational efficiencies are obtained, all the very good teachers are retained, and research can thrive with a fairer system of budgeting and selection. Somehow I doubt it. Cost cutting is difficult work. It's emotional. It affects people’s’ lives. But sometimes it's necessary to ensure the survival of the enterprise.

Academics can have practical knowledge and can have a tangible impact on society – it must be galling as the recipients of the ‘don’t come Monday’ letters consider the profligacy with which this government has distributed to consultants over failed or cancelled ‘ideas’ (of which ex-Minister Michael Woods takes the cake with the $50 million paid out for the proposed cycleway attached to the Auckland harbour bridge) In the year 2022 the taxpayers of NZ contributed almost $108 billion to help pay for the operation of this country. This compares with approximately $70 billion in 2017. A 54% increase in 5 years. We are spending $1 billion more every week than we were 5 years ago – and borrowing every dollar. Governments, just like families and businesses need to live within their means. When events occur, which inevitably they will, there must be a plan B. Unfortunately, under our present system of governance, many expect our politicians to manage and continue the policy of the previous governors, respond appropriately to cataclysmic events, foresee the future, and lead us along a well-trodden path for a purposeful life with wellness, meaning, and security. That isn’t going to happen. That’s what we need to do – and it starts at home and in school, learning how to learn.

Thanks Dad!

item.title: Thoughts from the Chair #7 (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
Synergy

Not a lot of downside in considering ‘Synergy’ as a means to enhance relationships, grow business, or develop teamwork. Couples, families, businesses of all sizes and types, team members, and of course, management and governments all prosper from co-ordination and cooperation. The rationale is that complementing strengths and weaknesses allows for greater heights of success – and of course, common goals, intentions, and aspirations being motivators for those committed.

Having said that, there are always outliers – business usually – for autocrats and single-minded CEOs. I suggest that Microsoft, Tesla, and Apple would not exist today without their founders having been – autocratic. Government ministers, council executives, and board directors often have tempestuous relationships with public servants, officials within administration, and or business management. But relationships don’t tend to last with narcissists. Teams, companies, and marriages require synergy for any long-term capability. And different types of leaders are often required to step in and build upon the founders, innovators, creators, foundations, or ideas.

What is interesting when reviewing successful sporting teams is the big difference a coach can make. They most often deflect personal attention, certainly deflect adulation to ‘the team’, and consistently outperform their competitors. (Pep Guardiola, Sir Alex Ferguson, Vince Lombardi, Sir Brian Lochore, Sir Wayne Smith, Scott Robertson) If a team, any team, sporting or otherwise is not performing – look at the leadership. When marriages break down – communication, collaboration, and compromise have either never existed or one of the parties believes that compatibility is irreconcilable – for any number of reasons.

What are the vital points of difference that a great coach can make, for couples, teams, business, soft and hard skills;

Passion (purpose)

Understanding (listening/philosophy)

Discipline (habits)

Commitment (dedication)

Persistence (determination)

Character (integrity/maturity)

Competence (technical ability)

Trust (reliability and truth)

I have followed and played team sports for many years and also coached sporting teams and business teams – with various levels of success. But it wasn’t until after my first marriage dissolved, that I began to truly grasp the importance of the list above and looked inward for the reason. It changed my life and made me a better coach (lifestage planner) manager (business) and partner (marriage) – to the extent, I’m eternally grateful to the people who have made up the ‘teams’ over my – 38 years (2nd) marriage, 27 years in business, and many years which followed in management.

What I know from having been many years as a financial adviser and lifestage planner is that people, couples, and business owners, appreciate receiving ongoing advice if it has good reason (destination/journey) is consistent with agreed principles and is authentic. In other words, there is an ongoing reviewable and measurable purpose – delivering value with practical outcomes and no BS.

The great coaches and successful long-term business owners know that “the whole is greater than the sum of its parts”.

Same at home.

Same in government – a leader might be admired but ‘the team’ will ultimately determine governance longevity.

item.title: Timing the market, or time in the market?
item.ns1:encoded:
In our June newsletter, we outlined the different strategies that we feel would be most appropriate for you, i.e. keeping cash in the bank, stock-picking, investing in many companies or alternative investments.

Let’s say you have met with your financial adviser, discussed the options, and decided on the strategy. Now it is time to invest.

Seeing the news and how the financial commentators provide their analysis, be it about the rising interest rates, supply chain issues, or the prospect of the economy going into recession, you decide to take a step back and reassess. Is now really the right time to invest?

With all the information received, the overall market prices might further decrease. Right?

So, should you invest now, wait, or dollar cost average into the market (put a smaller amount in your portfolio on a regular basis)?

Let’s look at a test by the Charles Schwab Corporation, who had compared 5 investing styles as below:

Consider five hypothetical investors all with different investment approaches, regarding timing their investing.

The following investors all had $2,000 at the beginning of the year to invest in the S&P 500 Index, for 20 years ending 2020.

1. Peter Perfect

Peter was extremely lucky as he had timed the market perfectly every year. (What are the chances of that?)

He waited and invested the $2,000 at the lowest point of each year. For example, in 2001, he invested in the S&P 500 on September 21, 2001 – the year’s lowest closing level.

2. Ashley Action

Ashley took immediate action, where she invested $2,000 in the market on the first trading day of the year.

3. Matthew Monthly

Matthew splits his $2,000 into 12 equal portions and invested each portion at the beginning of each month.

4. Unfortunate Umbridge

Ms. Umbridge had poor timing in investing in the market. She invested $2,000 each year at the market’s peak every year. (What are the chances of that?)

For example, in 2001, she had invested her $2,000 on January 30, 2001 – the year’s highest closing level.

5. Larry Linger

Larry anticipated purchasing when the market further plummets, however, decided to pull the handbrakes when the market prices went back up. He was convinced to keep his capital available to purchase stocks at lower prices that were just around the corner.

Larry eventually did not invest in the S&P 500 and invested in Treasury bills each year.

The results:

A study from Schwab Center for Financial Research found that in a span of 20 years from 2001 to 2020, Peter Perfect, who perfectly timed the market had the greatest return, while Ashley Action, came second, followed by Matthew Monthly, Unfortunate Umbridge, and lastly Larry Linger.

Source: Schwab Center for Financial Research. Invested $2,000 annually in a hypothetical portfolio that tracks the S&P 500® Index from 2001-2020.

The individual who never bought stocks in the example invested in a hypothetical portfolio that tracks the lbbotson U.S. 30-day Treasury Bill Index. Past performance is no guarantee of future results. Indexes are unmanaged, do not incur fees or expenses, and cannot be invested in directly. The examples are hypothetical and provided for illustrative purposes only. They are not intended to represent a specific investment product, and investors may not achieve similar results. Dividends and interest are assumed to have been reinvested, and the examples do not reflect the effects of taxes, expenses, or fees. Had fees, expenses, or taxes been considered, returns would have been substantially lower.

The difference between the first and second place is $15,920. While timing the market would be the most apparent approach, it is near impossible to time the market consistently over a long period of time.

Let’s take Covid’s recent impact on the market for example.

29 December 2019 - Chinese authorities advise the WHO of cases of pneumonia of unknown cause, originating in Wuhan, Hubei province[1].

9 - 15 March 2020 - Stock markets crashed after instability due to the pandemic. What some labeled as "Black Monday 2020" was, at that time, the Dow's worst single-day point drop in U.S. market history. Also, S&P 500’s lowest closing in 2020[2].

23 August 2020 - The losses from this record-breaking crash were fully recovered by 23 August, only five months after the market bottomed and while the global economy was still deep in a quagmire[3].

Timing the market requires an investor to preempt that once the news about Covid-19 broke out in December, the markets will go down. They actually went the other way for more than a month, before the sudden drop, through to mid- February when they reached their lowest point.

An investor who attempts to time the market not only had to predict the direction and movement of the market, but they also needed to pinpoint the lowest closing day of the year, consistently, which is extremely unlikely.

Timing the market requires an extensive time commitment, knowledge, and a large degree of luck. Because many investors are occupied with work, family, and other pursuits, they might not be able to invest at the lowest point of each year. Hence, investing immediately, or to dollar cost average is a more realistic approach to investing.

In the long run, it is better to be investing, even at the worst timing, than to not be investing at all.

item.title: Very disappointing review of the Insurance Industry by FMA & RBNZ
item.ns1:encoded:
Very disappointing review of the Insurance Industry by FMA & RBNZ

Read the full report HERE

 

Disclaimer, I am in the financial services industry and I am proud to say that among the many kinds of advice I provide to clients, that I include advice on insurance and sell them policies. I am also about to pop my head above the parapet.

I along with many others in our industry have long waited on and welcomed this review, and had high hopes for it, while for years we have jointly strived to lift standards and improve client outcomes ..........but what a disappointing and seemingly poorly researched piece of work it has turned out to be.

Yes, it has correctly identified several significant structural, system & conduct issues within the industry, but it then tried to justify its suggested drastic remediation, on statistically insignificant data sets either because, the data is insignificant, or it was less than in depth research.

I don’t in anyway suggest that any of the industries failings which affect clients are insignificant, and that they shouldn’t be repeated, and clients should be recompensed where they have been wronged. Nor do I disagree that some practises need to change, staff and adviser training improved, products lifecycles reviewed. I along with most good advisers welcome that. But, based on what has been produced, the changes mooted are the proverbial sledgehammer to crack a walnut.

The authors recommend urgent regulatory intervention to avoid what they must see as the risk of some financial apocalypse within the industry, when again, based on stats or anecdotal evidence in the report, less than .00004 clients are affected. (I made that stat up but its better than some justification I saw in the report)

Only once did the authors caution that their suggested fixes for the industry could lead to unintended consequences for clients. But then they ducked for cover and rather than suggest (a) what those might be and (b) how such unintended consequences might be mitigated, they implied “hey when we bring in these new changes if the public are disadvantaged then that’s the industries fault and the industry will have to fix our stuff up”.

I guess it was because it was so poorly researched the authors / researchers have chosen to be anonymous.

While its intentions are laudable, problems I see in this report are;

 

▪ Many times in the report it repeats that issues of conflicted remuneration leads to poor client outcomes and state the industry and advisers need to change to improve client
outcomes. They must have based much of that on hearsay because they only spoke to 29 advisers out of a possible pool of many thousands and no clients.

▪ What’s more, professional bodies who represent advisers such as FANZ, weren’t even identified in the report stakeholders within the industry or spoken to.

▪ It further recommends through out that the industry must be more client focussed - and I applaud that, but its extremely light on detail regarding supposed benefits that might flow to the millions of policy holders in NZ from the suggested drastic changes the authors demanded.

▪ What they have demanded will equate to multi-million-dollar investments in technology, training, product design, legal costs & client communication. If that is what is required then as an industry I hope all within it, embrace those changes. However, in the next breath, the authors seemingly ignoring the cost of such change, they suggest that by reducing commissions to advisers’ client’s premiums could be reduced by 12%. Really, where is the evidence for that, other than some bush maths? Have none of the authors ever been in business?

▪ When the insurers and industry start to implement the changes demanded, where do the authors think the money come from? It will come from paying less commission, which will probably mean less sales, less insured New Zealanders, but then any savings will be diverted not to cheaper premiums, but into funding the very investment which is required.

▪ The most damning is that no customers were spoken to! The authors only had to ask insurers or advisers, which they have the legal authority to do, to get access to thousands and thousands of names of customers to speak to. But I guess it wouldn’t have suited the tone of the report if it had to include customers who expressed satisfaction with their interactions with the industry. How can anyone on one hand demand the industry hold focus groups with consumers to find out what they want and be more client centric, and then on the other hand carry out a review of that industry, but fail to speak or consult with those you say you are trying to get better outcomes for?
Is it only what the authors think should happen that is important? 

So, while I’d hoped for a great outcome for clients and an improved industry from this review, in the end I fear this is not the report that will start to deliver that. The lack of customer input, and woeful business logic, will sadly mean the Government & regulators will get what they want, but customers may notice little real change. I pray I am wrong.

Scorecard


▪ Instigating research into the industry to improve outcomes for clients = A+

▪ Research undertaken, based on what they have put in the report = C-

▪ Reported stats to justify recommended changes = D

▪ Financial logic that reducing commissions and implementing the changes will enhance client outcomes & reduce premiums for clients = E

▪ Lack of research into what the unintended consequences of the changes will be for the consumer = E

 

Warwick Walker
AFA, CFP(CM)

item.title: Wealth Series, Part 6: What are the likely Lifestages (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
So what!

When we formed the company 27 years ago the foundations were determined to be holistic - (treating the whole person). Our intentions were to create a service business, related to financial products but aligned with people; transitions, traumas, and transactions throughout a lifetime. For that to occur we needed to offer choice (of products and suppliers) and to ensure that the offering would stack up for a lifetime, then through generations. We chose ‘Health, Wealth, Relationships, and Habits as our tagline’. Then we needed to re-educate, find the right staff, and upscale through improved processes and systems. An infrastructure to support continuity and succession.


The rationale has come from our own, our family’s, and our friends’ experiences of the previous 30 years – the health issues, the money issues, the relationship issues, and the habits which had helped to create or exacerbate those outcomes. Financial planning was not mainstream back in the mid-90s – but we had happened upon what was to become the ultimate framework for our growth and future; culture, values, and strategic approach with a conscious intent built on relationships for the long term. Delivered with professionalism and gold-standard service. Today the ‘Purpose’ (our why!) has evolved. ‘A life map to smooth the road, to ensure our client's financial affairs are in order, and there are no surprises, a planned and purposeful life with wellness, meaning, and security’ And a tagline of ‘Smooth the Road’

As my beautiful older sister tragically succumbs to the cruelty of Alzheimer’s, the reality of life and death continues its inevitable cycle for me to observe and participate in. The cycle of health, wealth, relationships, and habits. Each is intertwined – not just in old age, but throughout all our life and ultimately it will determine the length of our life. Whilst my sister’s family struggles with ‘the where and who’ to provide the care (it is beyond their capability) the ultimate reality of the fast-growing notion of our nation's demographic transition becomes even more obvious. Supply and demand for full-time aged care is no longer an ‘off the shelf’ solution. And now the financial issues become pronounced, the estate dissected (verbally initially then deconstructed in total for reallocation), and the pets, clothing, furniture, and personal items overseen with selective objectivism! One hopes. Money and Health and Relationships are there for all to see – in technicolour. Stark and real. Even whilst the life continues!

Lifestages (for total financial planning) commence a lot earlier (or for 6 life stages – 6 decades) in our 20s. – and ends somewhere nearer to ones 80s or 90s. In my case (my two sisters and me) lost both our parents in their 50s, and both Grannies in their 80s. I was only 21 when my father died of cancer. (in the early 70s) So there is no normal or easy and common pathway from birth to death – one needs to consider, and plan, so one can get on with ‘living’. If not, the trials and tribulations can become overwhelming – as is the observable reality of many in society today and is the foundation of fear used by both commercial and political entities. (A growing central state to assuage your feelings of helplessness – a growing reliance on pharmaceutical companies fostered by a health industry struggling to cope but delivering medication solutions with complex long-term consequences - a climate narrative focused on impending long-term doom when many are struggling to survive the week or the month due to inflation and a rising cost of living – and atrocities in both Eastern Europe and the Middle East.

Through various ‘lifestages’ differing circumstances prevail. In one's 20s there is usually a higher discretionary income, and the young haven’t yet taken on large amounts of debt (except for a student loan) Young people tend to spend rather than save but they are now much better financially speaking than in my generation because KiwiSaver has introduced a semi-compulsory investment habit. And with it – an awareness of asset classes albeit ‘not extensive’. The travel urge for young New Zealanders has not diminished - unfortunately many are not returning. How good would it be for the young to have formed good habits of, health, wealth, and relationships through one's 20s as opposed to more questionable behaviours and early ‘bad habits’? What a difference to the rest of their life! Good habits don’t stop having fun.

During age increases through the 30s, 40s, 50s, 60s, and 70s multiple life experiences and changes occur – and living seems to move faster as one progresses. It is not too late to start planning through any of these life stages – to align the products and services necessary with one’s goals, aspirations, or intentions. Banking, investing, insuring, estate management – with short-, medium-, and long-term goals. Anything well-planned and implemented at age 50 or 60 is a whole lot better than doing nothing. Taking advice at life stages can have a two-pronged positive influence – it may assist in making smarter financial decisions and give clarity to direction, but it may also prevent or lessen dumb ones.

It is incredibly hard for people to progress through life and the various life stages, without help/advice, whether medical, financial, or personal. For many of the ‘events’ through the various stages, it is too late to recapture the opportunity or to prevent the occurrence which happened in the stage previous. However, whilst many people can move on from regret, there is inevitably a cost – either financial mental or physical, but there is also an opportunity to; review one’s position, clarify intentions, measure, reset aspirations, and step forward with renewed optimism. After all most of NZ's small businesses, the self-employed, farmers, and corporates must do this on an ongoing basis. They have a plan (strategy) a constitution (the rules of the business) a board or mentor (external advice) and they revisit these intentions, regularly measuring execution and results on an ongoing basis. So too, successful sporting teams and athletes of all persuasions. Why don’t individuals or families do it? - that’s FoxPlan's opportunity.

From these learnings was formed a business – did it start as a complete package for people of all ages, no. But it has evolved and now delivers to a cross-section of New Zealanders, many of whom are considerably better off from having visited with our company and/or our advisers – whether specialist or generalist. We intend to progress indefinitely, to do so, succession and continuity are important for clients, FoxPlan personnel, and suppliers. We are constantly on the lookout for new personnel to teach and train and new clients to advise and service. We plan for a multigenerational contribution to our community – and a strong desire to deliver with a moral compass. Our Board, our shareholders, our constitution, and our staff, are committed to continuity for the business – not single generational profit and short-term payoffs. In other words, we intend to walk the talk of; long-term planning, holistic aspirations, professional execution and service, and client centricity. We are only in the early ‘stages’ of the life cycle – there are many decades yet to come.

item.title: Wealth Series, Part 2: What’s your number? How much is enough? (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
“A wealthy person has a significant net worth and passive income sources, making their financial future secure”.

 

It’s an important starting point – to know your goal. And for the purpose of interest – the goal is applicable, across all age ranges and at all lifestages. The only intelligent progression in the creation of net worth and passive income sources is; therefore, the goal (or goals), next the plan for achieving the goal(s), and only then the portfolio. The assumption is, an investment portfolio based on the major investment asset classes, of equities, commercial property, bonds, and cash.

For simplicity’s sake, I have assumed that the majority of people reading this article and the ‘wealth’ series are not likely to be SMEs, farmers, or tradies. Although at some point, you may have accumulated /invested, inherited, or created your wealth, there will come a time when a ‘portfolio’ becomes the major vehicle for the maintenance, enhancement, or facilitation of your plan – and the most effective means by which you can transfer that wealth to the next generation.

Therefore, sticking with the premise of ‘part #1.’ In this series (ie the light coming on at age 52)

  • You are a 52-year-old couple whose goal is to retire in 10 years at age 62. We’ve determined that at that time, you will want to withdraw from investments in inflation-adjusted dollars the equivalent of $75,000 today, over and above your anticipated NZ Government superannuation (currently available at age 65). In other words, you’ll need to withdraw at trendline inflation approximately $100,000 a year starting in 10 years (your KiwiSaver is currently not available for withdrawal until age 65)

  • You would like to maintain your wealth for multi-generational benefit and thus maintain the capital if possible – your legacy going to grandchildren and philanthropy. Assuming (a) your good health has been maintained (b) you have not made poor decisions around property (c) the cost of living/surviving has not escalated by way of retirement village costs etc, etc, etc.

  • We’ve agreed at retirement you’ll want to have two years of living expenses (or about $200,000) put aside in a money market fund, as a reserve for contingencies.

  • We further agree on a first-year withdrawal rate of 4.5% per year, with the cash withdrawal escalating at 3% per year to offset inflation in your living costs (we are using 3% as the trendline for inflation – as experienced on average over the last 100 years)

  • Specifically, to fully fund this plan you’ll need to accumulate $2.4 to $2.5 million in the next 10 years. That breaks down as (a) roughly $2.2 million to generate your $100,000 withdrawal assuming the 4.5% rate, plus (b) $200,000 more in reserve.

  • You currently have (x) in retirement funds accumulated via managed funds in at-work super (available at age 62) and KiwiSaver (available at age 65) and have committed to invest an additional (y) dollars in each of the 120 months until your projected retirement date. Based on those assumptions, you will need (example) an 8.7% compound return to reach your goal in 10 years.

  • Historically, a rate of return that high has only been achievable in equities/shares. We have selected a diversified equity fund / ETF portfolio, composed of (large cap/small cap/international/emerging markets) whose historical long-term return (net of our adviser fees at FoxPlan) has been 10%.

  • There can of course be no assurance of your achieving that return over the next 10 years. If you do not, adjustments may have to be made in terms of your investing more as you accumulate or working through for example, to age 65 (when your KiwiSaver becomes available), or scaling back your withdrawals in the early years of your retirement.

  • Equities subject your return and your capital to very wide variances. For example, the Standard and Poor's 500 – share/equity index has declined 14% annually on average since 1980. It has declined by an average of a third, once every 5/6 years. However, the closing price of the index in 1971 (the year you were born) was 98. Today it is over 4,000 (not considering dividends) Declines are temporary and time progressively leaches them out for the patient, disciplined investor.

  • We’ve agreed that our investment policy will be to continue investing as planned through any and all of the declines we may encounter over the next 10 years, in the hope of acquiring relatively lower-priced shares. Again, there can be no assurance that such a strategy will succeed.

  • We’ve agreed that we will review this strategy no less than annually, but that provided your goals do not change in the interim, we do not expect to alter materially either your plan or your portfolio.

 

By way of clarification – the writer has been assisting or providing direct financial planning and investment advice since before 1987. A date imprinted in many NZs' minds as a consequence of ‘the crash’! It is important to differentiate between ‘the stock market’ (what crashes and burns or shoots the lights out) which is a behavioural measure of investor emotion or mood swings as they react to media catastrophism – and the top 500 companies of the world. The managers of those top 500 companies are directly responsible to their boards and their shareholders – their capability, knowledge, and skill determine both personal and business outcomes – and unlike politicians, it is measured and reported regularly. They innovate, adapt, transition, pivot, and always focus on both short- and long-term strategies – and, weigh up risk.

 

In 1987 the S&P 500 (the top 500 companies in the US) (I always use this as the proxy for a managed fund portfolio of shares) – troughed at 223. Since then, a further eight 20% + declines have occurred. But as mentioned earlier, declines are temporary, and the growth of these companies is permanent (at the time of writing the S&P is 4,300)

Why is it so important to escalate the message around equities? – because it is seldom taught, most often denigrated inappropriately, poorly reported on by the media, and misunderstood even within the financial planning industry itself – to such a level that clients are led to misunderstand what the real risks are. The real risk in investment (using managed funds) is not volatility – but not knowing your goal, not understanding how to measure your required actions/inputs/criteria, and not understanding the only asset that is likely to get you to achieve your ultimate outcome.

 

Summarily – I hope it is clear that your goal will determine your number (how big a bag of money you need) the plan will determine how you reach it (the analysis, products, expectations) the portfolio the means by which we determine, what assets to use and why – and the review process held to hold each of the parties accountable to agreed decisions. It’s called lifestage planning.

 

Next week – Part 3. Principles and Practices of Successful Investment.

item.title: Wealth Series, Part 1: Living Life on Purpose (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
A 7-part sequence on what it means to different people of different ages. At what age the switch goes on and enlightens the former non-believers or the disinterested, the various myths and misconceptions which cloud an investor's mind, and the common mistakes people make when it comes to attaining financial peace of mind? 

Let’s clarify wealth – what is the difference between rich and wealthy? A rich person may have a significant income but may not have accumulated assets, leading to a less sustainable financial situation. On the other hand, a wealthy individual has a significant net worth and passive income sources, making their financial future more secure. 

This series is about ‘Wealth’ and some important understandings about why, how, and what 

  1. Statistics tell us that you are likely to be ‘retired’ for a third of your life 

  2. Tax will be the largest outgoing over a lifetime 

  3. Your home will likely cost you double what the purchase price was 

  4. If you have a health or employment hiccup through the accumulation years – you need to mitigate the risk (use a % age of income as your guide to cost the solution) 

  5. What size bag of money you require and how much risk mitigation is ‘enough’ are important questions for regular review 

So, we have a basis for the Wealth series 

  1. Living life on ‘purpose’ – life is for living 

  2. What’s your number? – how much is enough when income stops (for whatever reason) 

  3. Principles and practices – of successful investing 

  4. Why do I need advice? – the 8 great investment mistakes, and types of risks 

  5. Where’s the best place to start? – product, portfolio, property, self-employment 

  6. What are the likely lifestages I need to consider? – is an old people's home the destination? 

  7. Some statistics that might surprise you – and can I handle the facts? 

Part 1. Living life on purpose 

It never fails to amaze me why young people become ‘Max Verstappen-like’ when they get their cars onto the beach at Peka Peka or Foxton. What is the urge, and motivation to drive in tight circles – in the sand? Why would they even go near the saltwater in their cars – but they do.

Then there’s the young guys that ram raid. The car this time is a weapon – the one on the beach, some kind of reverie. Thrill seekers or hooligans. I suspect the latter will never become clients of our company – their behaviour points to a different sort of attitude/habit of thought. But what about those whose values match the market demographic for a company like FoxPlan – do their habits determine critical aspects of life? Sure do! Can they change – we shall see. 

What we know about people and money is that at about age 52, a switch ignites a financial reality check. At 51 their priorities revolved around ‘the Teslar’ or ‘the trip to Tahiti’ or ‘the Taupo bach’. At 52 it’s a Keto diet, enough money to chase the kids across the world, buy a campervan and/or continue to live an uninterrupted lifestyle. Suddenly the light goes on – and ‘How much is enough’ they quietly request. 

Well, you may not have left it too late by age 52 to have made the final journey to and through retirement – or corrected your diet, and exercise programme in time to walk the streets of Rome or the Peruvian Inca centre of worship at Machu Picchu. In fact, you may have already done your travel thing by then and now you want to grow tomatoes and make wooden toys! So be it. 

I’m a fan of people living life on purpose – their purpose. Life is for living and enjoying but I know from personal experience and experience gained from 25 years plus of giving lifestage planning advice that the destination and the journey can be enhanced with attention to aspects of – Health, Money, and Relationships. In fact, FoxPlan's basic premise, its original purpose was to address holistic lifestage planning – for people of all ages. Planning for a purposeful life.  

Of course, as our senior adviser team became more senior, the emphasis moved to some degree from; lending to leverage, from kids to campervans, from restaurants to retirement villages, from employment to enduring powers of attorney. That is why the company has continued to focus on recruitment and training – for staff and advisers. The future of our company, our community, and our country, depends on the treatment of its people. As a company we have a responsibility to ensure our clients from yesteryear are as financially secure and well set up for the last third of their life as we could possibly manage – and for that to be achieved, the company’s continuity plan necessitates an ongoing structure of support – and standards. New people, new technology, new procedures and systems, with old school standards of trustworthiness and authenticity. 

In other words – we have walked the talk. 25 years ago, we knew that for the company to keep its ‘promise’ to its clients there would need to be a changing of the guard, a changing of the guardhouse, and an investment for the future into technology and people. 

No different to how we intentionally suggest to our clients, be they business owners, self-employed, managers, administrators, professionals, mums, and dads – planning and structure, goals and aspirations, intentions, and direction, will assist longevity and lifestyle. 

 Wealth is not simply about how much we earn – it is much more than that. The wealth of the nation just like the wealth of a company, or a family is founded on trustworthiness – the six principles of which have been the foundation for FoxPlan over the past 25 years. And how about habits and behaviour – can the ‘young’ beach car enthusiast convert? Well, I haven’t exactly lived the last 70+ years as a monk – I remember Foxton Beach very well! Making smarter decisions helps – and everyone needs the opportunity – having someone to walk hand in hand with me was my smartest decision. 

 

Next week – ‘How much is enough?'

item.title: Wealth Series, Part 3: Principles and Practices of Successful Investment (Copy)
item.ns1:encoded:
The principles and practices (six concepts) are primarily focused on managed funds – these may include your KiwiSaver. The people and planning (six concepts) start to develop a broader concept of seeking ‘Wealth’ outcomes through various product and portfolio designs.

3 Principles

Faith  

Faith in there being a future, based on a system of economic science ie capitalism – you either trust that system and subscribe to an investment portfolio based on its continuation in something similar to its current format, or you do not. Vote #1.

Patience 

The future price of shares of consistently superior businesses are a direct function of their future earnings, dividends, and cash flows – history is our only certainty, we know the consistent growth of superior businesses because it has been measured for the last 100 years) You either subscribe to the belief that the upward trend of successful businesses has always bounced back from temporary declining markets, or you do not. Vote #2.

Discipline 

Markets are volatile because people are emotional, and they react – most often poorly) You understand that price and value are inversely related and thus continue to invest when markets decline in price, or you do not. Vote #3.

Of course, it is the responsibility of a ‘good’ financial adviser to advise, support, educate, and communicate (more in-depth) in the premise of these principles – anyone who values your business would be obliged to do so.

3 Practices

Asset allocation

What %age is in shares, what %age is in commercial property – ie growth assets, what %age is in bonds, what %age is in cash – ie fixed income assets

Diversification 

The global spread of products within each asset class – ie not only one company, not only one country, and not only one asset type within each ie small company shares, value company shares, large company shares, growth company shares – bonds with variable terms, and variable risk.

Re-balancing 

Reviewing annually to ensure portfolio structure matches the original plan and if through any particular reason, it does not – subscribing to a reasoned process of restructure ie just as any intelligent business owner would and does of necessity adapt, adjust to market disruption, so too the intelligent investor. That does not necessarily mean a change to asset allocation (unless the plan changes – see part 4 of the 3 Planning functions).

The financial and lifestage planner is of necessity for both an educator and a behavioural counsellor. Most poor financial and lifestage decisions are made from an emotional reaction and seldom include professional advice.

3 People Decisions

Advice vs DIY 

People seldom consider that the timeframe of investment and lifestage planning could be over 60 years and possibly inter-generational – and therefore making consistently good decisions and maintaining disciplines over this period is likely to be beyond them – especially if investing is not their ‘go’.

Product vs Planning using fund managers 

Most DIY investors think ‘return’ first, and most professional financial advisers think ‘risk’ first – investing is not gambling or speculating. Planning does not start with product consideration; it starts with having a mutually determined set of outcomes and having a plan of how they may be best accomplished.

Active vs Passive fund management 

Both are available and optional with most financial advisers – but one costs less than the other and, in most circumstances, outperforms over the long term – FoxPlan primarily focuses on passive funds management and uses external professionals for both investment management and compliant administration – and an administrative platform for online availability 24/7.

Property and term deposits were the primary investment considerations for individual personal investors in NZ when this author entered the finance industry in 1967. Banks seldom provided individual residential mortgage finance – that domain existed primarily with solicitors and building societies. The trend has remained, however – (apart from solicitors’ ‘trust’ funds) – NZs love property, but it has now created imbalance and unaffordability for many first-home buyers (if they don’t have family to assist with capital or security). Politicians will inevitably address this anomaly.

3 Planning Decisions

Cash management 

Assuming that the investor considers a plan to be superior to a product the lifestage planner has three important compartments to fill, advise, and recommend – they being first, income and expenditure and cash reserves (cash mgt), secondly, an investment portfolio which becomes the servant of the plan, and third, risk management which is the safety net of products which protect the client's accumulation phase and ultimate plan outcomes.

Investment Portfolio 

The structure and framework of investments necessary to achieve the investor's best possible means of achieving their investment and lifestage goals commensurate with their chosen lifestyle and attitude to risk – this may include their own business, KiwiSaver and managed funds, direct shares or fixed interest, direct property. This is about the linking of strategy and product with short-, medium-, and long-term goals.

Risk management 

Asset insurance, personal/family insurance, estate management, business key person and business risk – are products used for this purpose – and any investment product decision should have addressed potential risks in alignment with acceptance and awareness of possible consequences (both conservative and aggressive).

After many years of providing lifestage planning and investment advice to clients, it is with much pride and a positive conscience that I pass the baton onto our younger group of financial advisers – whilst they may not possess the 50 years of experience and accompanying market dynamic they have been chosen, trained and educated with the same dedication to morality, service, and professionalism with which the company has maintained its reputation and authenticity over the past 27 years. Next week, the 8 great investment mistakes and what the real risks are.
